title: The Sorting Sanctuary
story: Sorting is a fundamental algorithm! Python provides built-in functions to order your data. The sort() method modifies a list in-place, while sorted() returns a new sorted list without changing the original.
instructions: Create a list `numbers` with [5, 2, 8, 1, 9, 3]. Create `sorted_asc` using sorted() for ascending order. Create `sorted_desc` using sorted() with reverse=True. Sort the original list with sort(). Print sorted_asc, sorted_desc, and numbers.
solutionHidden:
numbers = [5, 2, 8, 1, 9, 3]
sorted_asc = sorted(numbers)
sorted_desc = sorted(numbers, reverse=True)
numbers.sort()
print(sorted_asc)
print(sorted_desc)
print(numbers)

tests.description: Should print all three sorted lists
tests.expectedBehavior: Output should show ascending, descending, and modified original

hints.text: sorted(list) returns new sorted list. list.sort() modifies in-place
Use reverse=True parameter for descending order: sorted(list, reverse=True)
sorted_asc = sorted(numbers), sorted_desc = sorted(numbers, reverse=True), numbers.sort()
